intro: Jacksonia scoparia, commonly known as the narrow-leaved flax, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as grasslands and rocky areas. Its narrow, linear leaves are arranged alternately along the stem, and it produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in spring. Jacksonia scoparia is often used in horticulture for its ornamental value and is adapted to dry, well-drained soils.
